questions.text: What is the Nissl-free zone from where an axon arises from a neuron called?
questions.solution:
The Nissl-free zone of a neuron from where an axon arises is called an axon hillock.

Nissl bodies or granules are aggregates of polyribosomes and rough endoplasmic reticulum. They are present in the cell body of a neuron and in large dendrites. Under light microscopy, they appear as basophilic granules. The affinity towards the basic dyes is due to the presence of a large amount of RNA which is acidic in nature. 

The image below shows a photomicrograph of bluish-coloured Nissl bodies (indicated by arrows) in the cytoplasm of motor neurons.

Option A: The initial segment refers to the proximal part of the axon, that lies just beyond the axon-hillock. Thus, an axon-hillock is part of the cell body while the initial segment is part of an axon.

Option B: Mesaxon refers to the area where the plasma membrane of the Schwann cell fuses with itself around the axon. During the formation of the myelin sheath, the axon invaginates the Schwann cell. The plasma membrane of the Schwann cell fuses with itself and continues to wrap around the axon to form multiple layers of the plasma membrane called the myelin sheath. The cytoplasm and nucleus of the Schwann cell are pushed to the periphery. The thin layer of the cytoplasm of the Schwann cell surrounding the myelin sheath is called neurilemma.

Option D: Each Schwann cell myelinates only a short segment of the axon. Hence, along the length of the axon, there are several Schwann cells myelinating it. The unmyelinated portions of the axon present in between myelinated segments are known as nodes of Ranvier.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and is now having multiple episodes of vomiting.On examination , GCS was 10, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated BP in this condition?
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for elevated BP in head injury patient is Cushing reflex.

As he has h/o head injury with fall in GCS and vomiting there might be associated intracranial bleed and thus the intracranial pressure will be elevated.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

Other options:

J Reflex

  • The juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors are C fiber endings located close to the pulmonary vessels.
  • These are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung
  • Produces rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Atrial reflex control of heart rate: The Bainbridge Reflex

  • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain
  • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction

Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

  • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery)
  • Causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

questions.text:
Match the following mucopolysaccharidoses with the defective enzyme in each case:
Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
2. Morquio syndrome B B. Iduronate sulfatase
3. Hurler syndrome C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A D. β-galactosidase
questions.solution:
The option showing 1-B, 2-D 3-A, 4-C  is correctly matched.

Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome B. Iduronate sulfatase
2. Morquio syndrome B D. β-galactosidase
3. Hurler syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase

 

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. When they are attached to a protein they are referred to as proteoglycans. These proteoglycans make up a large part of the extracellular matrix and connective tissue.

Defects in the enzymes that degrade GAGs result in the mucopolysaccharidoses mentioned above. These defects are commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Accumulation of GAGs in the tissue can result in organomegaly, cartilage and bone abnormalities, facial abnormalities, problems with mental development, etc.

Related Pearl: Biologically important Glycosoaminoglycans(GAG's)

GAG

Disaccharide repeat units

Keratan sulfate

N Acetyl Glucosamine + Galactose

Hyaluronic acid

N Acetyl Glucosamine + Glucuronic acid

Chondroitin sulfate

N Acetyl Galactosamine + Glucuronic acid

Dermatan Sulfate

N Acetyl Galactosamine + Iduronic/ Glucuronic acid

Heparan sulfate

N Acetyl(Fewer N-sulphated than Heparin)Glucosamine + Glucuronic acid

Heparin

N Sulphated Glucosamine + Iduronic acid

questions.text: A child who was stung multiple times after disturbing a bee hive developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse within minutes. Which of the following is the principal mediators of this reaction?
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following a bee sting is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or Type 1 hypersensitivity and the principal mediator involved here is histamine.

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies. It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to an IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals. 

Activation of TH2 cells is mediated by IL-4 and in turn, TH2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines act on B cells to stimulate IgE and activation of eosinophils. IgE coats mast cells by binding to the FcεRI receptor. Re-exposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI which in turn causes activation of mast cells releasing powerful mediators. The principal mediators are:

  • Histamine
  • Proteases
  • Prostaglandins
  • Leukotrienes
  • Cytokines like TNF, IL-1, and chemokines.

The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis. It occurs in two phases: 

  • The immediate phase is characterized by vasodilation, vascular leakage, smooth muscle spasm (in asthma), or glandular secretions. These changes occur within minutes after exposure to an allergen and subside in a few hours.
  • Late-phase reaction is characterized by infiltration of tissues with eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and CD4+ T cells. Late-phase reaction sets in 2 to 24 hours later and may last for several days.

Image: Sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical Syndrome

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Anaphylaxis (may be caused by drugs, bee sting, food)

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Bronchial asthma

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Allergic rhinitis, sinusitis (hay fever)

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), which is a superantigen.

Superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and Vβ region of the TCR.

Some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin.

The below image shows the binding of superantigen to T-cell receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the first-line drug used in the treatment of Trigeminal neuralgia ?

choices.text: It is a GABAc receptor modulator
It can lead to hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.solution:
Carbamazepine is the primary agent for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia which is a Sodium-channel blocker.

It slows the recovery rate of voltage-activated sodium channels from their inactivated state.

Carbamazepine is most effective in complex partial seizures. It is also used in GTCS and simple partial seizures, trigeminal and related neuralgias, manic depressive psychosis.

Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause leukopenia, aplastic anemia, or hepato-toxicity and hyponatremia in the elderly.

Idiosyncratic blood dyscrasias with carbamazepine, include fatal cases of aplastic anaemia and agranulocytosis. The most common idiosyncratic reaction is an erythematous skin rash. It can rarely cause Steven Johnson Syndrome.

Mechanism of action of some common antiepileptics:

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the legal term corpus delicti?
questions.solution:
Corpus delicti, also known as the body of offense, says that a crime must be proved to have occurred before a person can be convicted of committing that crime.

The main part of corpus delicti is the establishment of the identity of the dead body and infliction of violence in a particular way, at a particular time and place, by the person or persons charged with a crime and none other. 

A conviction for an offense does not necessarily depend upon the corpus delicti if there are eyewitnesses or strong corroborative evidence.

In a charge of homicide, it includes:

  • Positive identification of the dead body (victim)
  • Proof of its death by a criminal act of the accused

questions.text: The image depicts
questions.solution:
Image shows Cottle test where cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly.
If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates abnormality of the vestibular component of nasal valve.
Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in treatment of BPPV.
Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is followed in accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.
Option D: Trotter’s method is used in treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding with-the-rule astigmatism?

choices.text: The horizontal meridian is more myopic.
The vertical meridian is more myopic.
The vertical meridian is more hyperopic.
The horizontal meridian is more hyperopic.

questions.solution:
In with-the-rule astigmatism, the curvature of the vertical meridian is more than the horizontal meridian. Greater the curvature, more the myopia. Hence, the vertical meridian is more myopic in with-the-rule astigmatism.

Note: In normal conditions, the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal meridian. Astigmatism that follows this pattern (wherein the vertical curvature is more than the horizontal curvature), is known as with-the-rule astigmatism. Irrespective of the type of with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is always more myopic (curved) than the horizontal meridian.

questions.text: The cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is:
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is IV fluids.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. And often patients respond well to supportive management.

Platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleeding.

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs in dengue include 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised for all patients with dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: In order to effectively prevent endemic goiter, what is the recommended iodine content in salt at the consumer level?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of iodine content in salt is 15 ppm at the consumer level and 30 ppm at the production level.

The iodization of salt is used as a prophylactic measure against endemic goiter. In India, the level of iodization is fixed under the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. On examination, pallor was noted. Peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first presentation of alcoholic liver disease?
questions.solution:
Fatty infiltration or Alcoholic Fatty Liver is the most common and initial response to hepatotoxic insult of excessive alcohol consumption.

Alcohol Liver Disease refers to a spectrum of liver injuries that progress in the following order:

  • Alcoholic Fatty Liver
  • Alcoholic Steatohepatitis - mixed pattern of fatty infiltration and inflammation of hepatocytes
  • Alcoholic Cirrhosis - Micronodular cirrhosis (< 3 mm in diameter). Cessation of alcohol leads to the development of larger nodules showing a mixed micronodular and macronodular pattern.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of medication overuse headache.

Medication overuse headache is the headache occurring on ≥15 days/month due to overuse of headache medications for>3 months. It is also known as analgesic rebound headache, drug-induced headache, or medication-misuse headache. It usually resolves when the overuse is stopped.

Management: It includes the following steps:

  • Withdrawal of the overused medication
  • Treatment of withdrawal symptoms
  • Initiation of preventative therapy if required
  • Alternative symptomatic medication for future headaches

Other options:

Option B: Tension headache is a chronic headache syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight band-like discomfort. It can be episodic or chronic in nature. It is usually not associated with nausea, vomiting, etc.

Option C: Chronic migraine - Diagnostic criteria for migraine headache is as follows: Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 hours in patients with normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for headache, and

At least 2 of the following features Plus at least 1 of the following features
Unilateral pain Nausea or vomiting
Throbbing pain Photophobia and phonophobia
Aggravation by movement  
Moderate or severe intensity  

Option D: Cluster headache is characterized by deep, excruciating, nonfluctuating pain which is usually retroorbital. The classical feature of this condition is its periodicity.  At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at almost the same hour every day.
Typically the patient has daily bouts of one or two attacks of relatively short-duration unilateral pain for 8–10 weeks a year. In between the clusters, there is a pain-free interval.

questions.text: A patient with acute hepatitis B has recovered from the infection. Identify the serological marker marked in the image:
questions.solution:
The serological marker marked in the image is anti-HBc Ab. It remains elevated for a long period after recovery from infection.

Anti-HBc is readily demonstrable in serum, beginning within the first 1–2 weeks after the appearance of HBsAg. It precedes detectable levels of anti-HBs by weeks to months. IgM anti-HBcAg antibody is seen early in the infection for about 6 months and indicates a recent infection. Whereas, IgG anti-HBcAg antibody is the immunoglobulin class seen later i.e. after 6 months, and indicates remote infection.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - - - IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - + IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

HBV infection in the remote past

questions.text: Paraneoplastic syndrome is usually associated with which type of lung cancer?
questions.solution:
• Paraneoplastic Syndrome is usually associated with small cell carcinoma.
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma is associated with Smoking and Central necrosis.
  • Adenocarcinoma Metastasize earlier and is more common in women, it is the most common type of Carcinoma lung worldwide.

questions.text:
Triple assessment includes

1. History
2. Clinical examination
3. Radiological investigations
4. Histopathological examination
questions.solution:
Triple assessment in relation to breast carcinoma includes the following:

  • History and clinical examination
  • Radiological imaging, including ultrasonography (USG) and/or mammography
  • Histopathological examination (HPE), including fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and/or Tru-Cut biopsy

The positive predictive value of the triple assessment is 99.9%.

Note: In Bailey & Love 27th Ed, Pg 863, it is mentioned that clinical assessment, radiological imaging, and HPE constitute triple assessment. However, clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination. Hence, history is a part of triple assessment.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient has undergone unilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s syndrome and you have been asked to start him on cortisol supplementation, post-surgery. What is the rationale behind it?

choices.text: Remaining  adrenal gland has insufficient reserve
Contralateral adrenal gland is suppressed by prolonged cortisol over-secretion

questions.solution:
The rationale behind cortisol supplementation after the surgical removal of the adenoma is that there is suppression of the contralateral adrenal gland by the pre-operative elevated cortisol levels. This causes primary adrenal insufficiency.

Patients undergoing unilateral adrenalectomy typically require exogenous steroids for up to a year, which is usually the duration the remaining adrenal gland takes to recover adequate function. In bilateral adrenalectomy, steroids are required indefinitely, and patients may also require mineralocorticoid replacement therapy. 

Option A: The remaining adrenal gland usually has sufficient reserve to maintain homeostasis.

Option C: A deficiency of ACTH causes secondary adrenal insufficiency. However, the adrenal insufficiency post adrenalectomy is primary i.e due to the hyposecretion of cortisol from the gland itself. 

Option D: Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome is a bilateral adrenal infarction associated with meningococcal sepsis and is rapidly fatal unless immediately treated.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of Nissen's fundoplication?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is gas-bloat syndrome. 

Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus.

After this procedure, most patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the esophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach resulting in bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. This is known as gas bloat syndrome and occurs more commonly with Nissen total fundoplication.

Pneumothorax is the most common complication that occurs intraoperatively.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised?
questions.solution:
The final switch to heparin in pregnant women is advised at 36 weeks of pregnancy.

The American College of Chest Physicians Guidelines for Anticoagulation of Pregnant Women is given below:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it by heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) can also be used.
  • After the 12th week, it is replaced by warfarin and continued up to 36 weeks.
  • Thereafter it is replaced by heparin which is discontinued just before delivery.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after cesarean section.
  • UFH (unfractionated heparin), LMWH and Warfarin therapy are not contraindicated during breastfeeding.

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. The appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) would be ______
questions.solution:
The dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) in this case is 800 mcg.
Mucosal misoprostol administration has increased efficacy and minimizes gastrointestinal side effects and is now preferred over the prior oral administration. The mucosal route includes buccal, sublingual, and vaginal Misoprostol administration.


Medical management protocol for induced abortion for < 12 weeks of gestation (As per WHO 2018 guideline):

  • Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol
  • Misoprostol only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually, or buccally.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9weeks)

First trimester 

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol

Misoprostol only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually or buccally.

Methotrexate/Misoprostol

(d) Methotrexate, 50 mg/m2 body surface area intramuscularly or orally; followed in 3-7 days by:

(e) Misoprostol, 800 mcg vaginally. Repeat if needed 1 week after methotrexate initially given

 
Second Trimester

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended) : 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Misoprostol Alone(Alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Dinoprostone

20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr

Concentrated Oxytocin

50 units oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused during 3 hr; then 1-hr diuresis (no oxytocin); then escalate sequentially in a similar fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units oxytocin each in 500 mL normal saline
 

Note: This recommendation has been updated from the WHO 2012 Safe abortion guidance. This updated recommendation applies to pregnancies up to 12 weeks of gestation, whereas, in the prior guidance, different regimens were recommended for pregnancies up to 7 weeks, 9 weeks, and 12 weeks.

questions.text: Which among the given features is not a major physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Among the given features hypothyroidism is not a major physiological change in pregnancy.

The α-subunits of hCG and TSH are identical. An increase in hCG during pregnancy stimulates thyroid and leads to a decrease in TSH levels. The thyroid undergoes enlargement and boosts the production of hormones. This is accompanied by increased production of thyroid-binding globulin(TBG). All these changes increase total T4 and T3 in the first trimester. But the physiologically important free T4 and T3 levels remain unchanged. Hence, physiologically pregnant women remain euthyroid.

Option A: Normal pregnancy is characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Human placental lactogen(hPL) secreted during pregnancy, helps in adaptation to fetal energy requirements. Insulin resistance causes prolonged hyperglycemia and glucose flow to the fetus. It also favours protein synthesis. To counterbalance the increased insulin resistance and prevent maternal hyperglycemia, maternal insulin levels are increased.

Option B: By the 3rd trimester, there is an increase in the maternal basal metabolic rate by 10 to 20% in comparison to a nonpregnant woman.

Option D: During normal pregnancy, mean arterial pressure and vascular resistance decrease, while blood volume and cardiac output rate increase. This helps in meeting metabolic demands of the enlarged uterus, provide nutrients to rapidly growing placenta and fetus, safeguard mother against the effects of parturition-associated blood loss.

questions.text: Sabareesh, a 7-year-old boy was playing football with his friends during the PET classes. Suddenly he complained of severe abdominal pain and he is rushed to the pediatric ER.  An erect X-ray scan of the abdomen showed the following picture.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sigmoid volvulus is the most likely diagnosis. It occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. It is a cause of large bowel obstruction.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text: An elderly male has pain and swelling in the knee joint.  Synovial fluid on polarized light microscopy demonstrated
questions.solution:
The given case is highly suggestive of pseudogout and in the study of synovial aspirate on polarized light, the crystals appear as Positively birefringent rhomboid shaped crystals

Crystals on Polarised Microscopy
Gout Pseudogout
Negatively Birefringent Positviely birefringent
Needle Shaped Rhomboid crystals
Na Urate(Sodium Urate) Ca pyrophosphate

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?
questions.solution:
Postpartum blues is common in mothers in the puerperal period and requires nothing more than education and support. It is characterised by a labile mood, sadness and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood.

If symptoms last longer than 2 weeks, an evaluation for postpartum depression is needed.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: A 26-year-old term primigravida is taken to the operation theatre for an emergency cesarean section due to sudden fetal distress. The anaesthetist wants to prevent chances of pulmonary aspiration and decides to intubate using rapid sequence intubation. Which of the following steps is not performed in this technique?
questions.solution:
Bag and mask ventilation is avoided in rapid sequence intubation because it leads to stomach inflation and increases the risk of aspiration.

Indications of Rapid sequence intubation:

RSI is done when the patient is at increased risk of pulmonary aspiration as in:

  • pregnancy
  • full stomach
  • intestinal obstruction
  • hiatus hernia
  • encephalopathy
  • morbid obesity
  • diabetic gastroparesis.

questions.text: A patient presented with scaly lesions as shown in the image below. He later developed arthritis and nail changes.  What is the treatment of choice for this?
questions.solution:
The patient has right knee effusion, dactylitis of multiple digits, and sharply demarcated scaly red papulosquamous lesions on both knees all of which point toward a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Methotrexate and apremilast are the first-line drugs for the treatment of moderate to severe psoriasis associated with psoriatic arthritis.

Features of psoriatic arthritis are :

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
  • associated with nail pitting/ onycholysis, or
  • dactylitis, enthesitis 
  • Inflammation is prominent in the distal interphalangeal joints 
  • There is dactylitis with pronounced telescoping.
  • Nail dystrophy (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis) affects each of the fingers
  • Axial involvement may occur

Radiological features:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of DIP joint
  • marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation "whiskering"
  • small joint ankylosis
  • Ray distribution of lesions

Indications for methotrexate (inflammatory conditions) include:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis 
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Polymyositis
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Giant cell arteritis 
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Other systemic vasculitis
  • Graft versus host disease associated with organ transplantation.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: A young woman presented to the OPD with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. She was diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia 3 months back. Barium swallow was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing esophageal web is suggestive of Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome. It is more common in women and is a recognized risk factor for post cricoid hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.

 It consists of the following features:
  1. Dysphagia 
  2. Iron-deficiency anemia     
  3. Esophageal webs or hypopharyngeal webs

The image below depicts a barium swallow showing an upper esophageal concentric web in lateral view. These are due to an esophageal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen. More commonly, they are seen in the cervical esophagus near the cricopharyngeus muscle. They typically arise from the anterior wall, but never from the posterior wall. They may also be circumferential.

questions.text: All are causes of high RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) except:
questions.solution:
Subacute thyroiditis shows low uptake of radioactive iodine as it involves destruction and inflammation of the thyroid follicles, which also accounts for the thyrotoxic symptoms due to exocytosis of the hormone.

The other three are classical examples of high RAIU.

Radioactive Iodine Scan:

  • Nonpregnant, hyperthyroid patients with physical examination suggesting nodular thyroid disease, radioactive iodine should be the initial test to determine the aetiology of hyperthyroidism.
  • Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications to radionuclide imaging.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a high (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates either inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of preformed hormone into the circulation or an extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone, such as in patients with factitious thyrotoxicosis and in patients with struma ovari.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Drug-induced—amiodarone, iodine
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)
